The question paper is made up of a variety

85.text:
of question types including 1 mark recall
questions and two, three and four mark questions,

95.text:
requiring recall and application of knowledge
to achieve maximum marks. There are more stretching

102.text:
questions worth 5 and 6 marks. Finally there
are the extended answer questions worth 12

110.text:
marks which require learners to present lengthy,
connected points or arguments relevant to

117.text:
the question context. This presentation will
look at a number of these different types

126.text:
The first question we shall consider is question
2 on page 3 of the question paper. This was

134.text:
a straight forward question as candidates
were required to 'define' the term sedentary

142.text:
lifestyle, they then had to 'explain' why
a sedentary lifestyle is a contemporary concern.

149.text:
As you can see from the example some learners
gave excellent responses gaining full marks.

157.text:
In this example credit is given for 2a as
the learner states 'a lifestyle that is lacking

165.text:
in physical activity' for 1 mark. Then in
2b credit is given for 'topical issue of relevance

175.text:
in today's society', 'increase in hypokinetic
disorders', 'poor diet', 'is a strain on NHS'

182.text:
to gain the maximum 4 marks.
In this response the learner has gained 1

199.text:
mark in 2a for 'a lifestyle that does not
include physical activity'. They went on to

207.text:
gain all 4 marks available for 2b by writing
'leads to obesity', 'unhealthy diet', 'sedentary

218.text:
lifestyles increase risk of diabetes, high
blood pressure, coronary heart disease (illness)'

226.text:
and 'more pressure on NHS'.
This learner gains 1 mark in 2a for 'a lifestyle

240.text:
lacking in physical activity'. However, they
only get 1 mark for 2b when they state 'sedentary

249.text:
lifestyle has become a concern in recent years'.
There is no rewardable material present in

257.text:
the rest of the response.
Learners who did well on this question:

268.text:
Applied their knowledge to the question context
eg they could define sedentary lifestyle.

276.text:
Selected appropriate reasons as to why sedentary
lifestyle is a contemporary concern.

283.text:
Most candidates showed an understanding of
society becoming more sedentary for some credit,

290.text:
but this could be improved by extending the
response to give the consequences of this.

297.text:
Further examples of learner responses can
be found in the Lead Examiner's report.

303.text:
An example of a 'describe' type question is
Q6bi and ii, and each part of the question

318.text:
is credited with three marks. Knowledge needs
to be applied and described to gain maximum

326.text:
marks.
Many students listed characteristics of activities,

332.text:
or listed characteristics of life during the
periods of time. However the question asks

339.text:
candidates to 'describe how the physical activities
reflected British society' Consequently the

348.text:
two concepts had to be linked in order to
score the marks. Linking words were helpful

355.text:
for the examiner (see underlined).
In this first example the candidate scores

363.text:
all three marks for Q6bi. They describe the
fact that 'lack of transport caused the activities

372.text:
to be localised', 'they were rural as people
lived in the countryside' and 'cruel as society

383.text:
A further 3 marks were awarded for Q6bii where
the learner had correctly described the facts

391.text:
that 'there was education to make rules and
write them down (making a link between the

398.text:
fact that now educated the populous could
read them)', 'they had boundaries with fewer

407.text:
players due to lack of space' and that they
'became regular as everyone had Saturday afternoon

415.text:
off'.
Maximum marks were awarded for this answer.

426.text:
Q6bi gained three marks for 'localised as
there was a lack of transport', 'cruel as

434.text:
reflected barbaric society' and 'games were
un-coded as majority were illiterate'.

442.text:
A further three marks were awarded for Q6bii
for 'less violent as there was a need for

452.text:
a healthy work force', 'boundaries were created
due to lack of space' and 'education was compulsory

462.text:
and rules could be written down'.
This learner gained no marks on either part

474.text:
of the question. There was no rewardable material
because in both Q6bi and Q6bii they failed

484.text:
to link the physical activities descriptions
to how they reflected society at the time.

490.text:
For example in Q6bi they correctly described
that Pre Industrial physical activities had

499.text:
few rules but then did not make a correct
link to how this reflected the society at

505.text:
the time, such as they were uneducated.
Learners did well on this question because:

519.text:
They linked their response to the question
context.

522.text:
They correctly described how physical activities
carried out during both the pre and post Industrial

530.text:
Revolution reflected British society at that
time.

535.text:

extend their response but responses could

providing clearer examples or linkage between

Activity 1 Q7 was a true mark of 5.
There are important points to note regarding

627.text:
this question. There are six marks available;
therefore learners should consider six different

634.text:
points that can be made.
In this example the learner gains credit for

640.text:
point 6 on the m/s, ie taking part; point
8 as public school boys took games to university;

650.text:
point 12 for students left university and
created work teams; point 11 for reference

657.text:
to National Governing Bodies; and point 10
for mention of national rules. No further

665.text:
credit was given to this response ie no credit
for sportsmanship or the Olympics, thus the

673.text:
learner gained 5 of the available 6 marks.
On this question successful candidates:

685.text:
Used specific examples linked to the given
context.

690.text:
Used accurate vocabulary eg Melting Pot, Oxbridge.
Could explain the phrase exporting the games

699.text:
ethic.
On this question less successful candidates:

709.text:
Struggled with an understanding of what 'exporting'
means.

714.text:
Failed to relate their answers to the given
context.

717.text:
Used inaccurate technical vocabulary.
Failed to explain what is meant by the phrase

723.text:
exporting the games ethic.
Failed to give the appropriate amount of answers

729.text:
for the marks required.
Maximum marks were awarded for this answer.

sport'.

answer. Marks were awarded for 'screening

10 they would go to sports boarding schools',
'6 hours of sport and 2 hours of lessons'

This learner only scored 1 mark for 'screening

Failed to relate their answers to the given

Before looking at these it is helpful first
to consider the different types of mark scheme

939.text:
that are used within the paper, an understanding

945.text: demands of these types of question.

948.text:
The reason for the two approaches to marking
is because different questions test different

956.text:
skills. All of the questions we have looked
at so far have used a points based approach

962.text:
to marking. However, levels based mark schemes
are used when the possible scope of responses

970.text:
are not limited, when it is not possible to
think of every possible correct answer or

976.text:
when we need to make judgments about how well
a response addresses discursive or evaluative

Activity 2 Q9 was a true mark of 10 which

1062.text:
means that it is a Level 4 answer.
The learner has produced a comprehensive explanation

1069.text:
that is coherent and includes good detail.
It is worth noting that although not all points

1076.text:
on the mark scheme are covered here, that
this is not essential. The indicative content

1082.text:
is only a guide to the responses learners
may give. Other valid responses which answer

1089.text:
the question correctly can be credited as
appropriate. For example, the learner has

1095.text:
made the link between a massive spectator
base and influential media with the changing

1102.text:
nature of some sports, to make them fast paced
and exciting. They have also produced a counter

1109.text:
argument to point 3 on the mark scheme that
a disadvantage would be that some minority

1115.text: sports are in danger of becoming side-lined.

1118.text:
The answer is balanced eg it gives equal measure
to the advantages and the disadvantages associated

1128.text:

sport.

1131.text:

present, which whilst not compulsory add to

Question 9 Why candidates did well:

1201.text:
They:
Discussed the advantages and the disadvantages

1205.text:
associated with the level of commercialisation
in modern sport in equal measure.

1211.text:
Gave a comprehensive explanation that was
coherent and included full detail.

1218.text:
The subject specific terminology was used
with minimal error.

1225.text:
Showed original thought and where appropriate
supplied up-to-date and relevant examples

1232.text:
to support their argument.
Wrote responses which had clear and effective

1237.text:

1245.text: Question 9 Why candidates didn't do so well:

1255.text:
Some failed to link the points they were making
to develop their argument.

1260.text:
Some gave unbalanced answers focusing on either
the advantages or the disadvantages but not

1267.text:
both which they were required to do.
Some focused on one aspect of deviance such

1273.text:
as drug taking rather than making a range
of points about the possible rise of deviance.

1280.text:
Many learners simply wrote an answer which
did not relate specifically to the question

1286.text:
asked.
Others penned answers that were formulaic

1290.text:
with bland assertions and no debate or analysis
of the topic concerned.

1298.text:
Common Issues
Not making enough use of the given scenario

1307.text:
within answers.
Answers should be contextual.

1312.text:
Variable quality, accuracy and level of content
in the answers produced.

1319.text:
Generic 'prepared' answers. Examples not being
specific enough to the requirement of the

1326.text:
question.
Variable understanding of technical vocabulary.

1331.text:
A lack of clarity in explanations/examples
makes it difficult to establish if the learner

1339.text:
really understands.
Learners do not always develop their responses

1345.text:
even when the mark range and phrasing of the
question shows a more in-depth response is

1352.text:
required.
Dropped marks by not giving enough points

1357.text: to cover the score for the question.

1371.text:
Opinion + substantiated mid band.
Opinion, substantiated + example high band.

1381.text:
Opinion, substantiated, contrasting examples
+ balanced argument = Top band.
